g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute
To assess the technical mitigation potentials of Indian agriculture and costs under a Business as Usual
scenario (BAU) and Mitigation scenario up to 2030
The study shows that by 2030 under BAU scenario GHG emissions from the agricultural sector in India
and IPCC AR4 values) with a technical mitigation potential
s mitigation practices. About 80% of the technical
mitigation potential could be achieved by adopting cost
saving measures. Three mitigation options, i.e.,
water management, could deliver more than 50%
total technical abatement potential. Under the BAU scenario the projected GHG emissions from major
crop and livestock species is estimated at 489 MtCO
eq in 2030, whereas under mitigation scenario
GHG emissions are estimated at 410 MtCO
g a technical mitigation option of about 78.67
(Box 7.6, Figure 1). Major sources of projected emissions under the BAU scenario, in
order of importance, were cattle, rice, buffalo, and small ruminants. Although livestock production and
ultivation account for a major share of agricultural emissions, the highest mitigation potential was
). Crops such as cotton and sugarcane each offered
while the mitigation potential from small ruminants
also estimated the magnitude of GHG savings per year through adoption of various
mitigation measures, together with the total cost and net cost per unit of
itional benefits of increased yield due to adoption of the mitigation measures were considered, about
80% of the technical mitigation potential (67.5 out of 85.5
measures. When yield benefits were considered, gree
n fodder supplements to ruminant diets
effective mitigation measure, followed by vermicomposting and improved diet management
of small ruminants. Mitigation measures such as fertigation and micro
degraded land and feed additives in livestock appear to be cost
considering yield benefits, if any. The study accounted for GHG emissions at the farm level and
excluded emissions arising due to processing, marketing or consumption po
include emissions from feed production, since livestock in India mostly rely on crop by
Further the potential of laser land levelling seems exaggerated which may also be
ted potential from ‘improved water management in rice’. The mitigation
ecological approaches/technologies such as natural farming which is picking up in
India in recent years has also been overlooked.
